Savory Thai Basil Stir-Fry

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to your new favorite weeknight meal – Savory Thai Basil Stir-Fry! This vibrant dish is a delightful blend of fresh ingredients and bold flavors, perfect for anyone who loves a quick, satisfying meal that doesn’t compromise on taste. With tender chicken breast or tofu, colorful bell peppers, and aromatic Thai basil, this stir-fry is as nutritious as it is delicious. Whether you’re a seasoned cook or a kitchen novice, you’ll find that this recipe is not only simple but also adaptable to your preferences. You can easily swap out the protein or add in your favorite vegetables. Plus, the dish comes together in just under 30 minutes, making it an excellent choice for busy weeknights. Get ready to impress your family and friends with this authentic taste of Thailand right in your own home!

Ingredients

chicken breast (or tofu)

For chicken, choose boneless, skinless breasts for quick cooking. If using tofu, opt for firm or extra-firm tofu, and press it to remove excess moisture before cubing. For a flavor boost, marinate the protein in a mixture of soy sauce, garlic, and a dash of sesame oil for 30 minutes before cooking.

fresh thai basil

Thai basil has a unique flavor that differs from sweet basil; it’s slightly spicy and anise-flavored. If you can’t find Thai basil, you can substitute with a mix of sweet basil and a little bit of mint, or use regular basil with a pinch of fennel seeds to mimic the flavor.

bell peppers (sliced)

Use a mix of red, yellow, and green bell peppers for a colorful dish. They can be sliced into thin strips for quicker cooking. If you want extra sweetness, roast the peppers before adding them to the stir-fry.

onion (sliced)

Use yellow or red onions for a sweeter flavor. Slice them thinly to ensure they cook quickly and integrate well with the other ingredients. For added depth, consider adding a splash of balsamic vinegar or a pinch of sugar while sautéing.

garlic (minced)

Fresh garlic is best for this recipe. Mince it finely for a stronger flavor and add it to the pan before the onions to infuse the oil. If you want a milder garlic flavor, you can add it later in the cooking process.

soy sauce

Opt for low-sodium soy sauce to control the saltiness of your dish. For a gluten-free option, use tamari instead. You can also experiment with adding a bit of dark soy sauce for a richer color and deeper flavor.

oyster sauce (or vegetarian alternative)

If you’re vegetarian, use mushroom oyster sauce for a similar umami flavor. Regular oyster sauce can enhance the dish's richness; be mindful of the amount as it can be quite salty.

vegetable oil

Choose a high smoke point oil like canola, peanut, or grapeseed oil for stir-frying. This will allow you to cook at higher temperatures without burning the oil.

red pepper flakes (optional)

Adjust the quantity based on your spice tolerance. For a more complex heat, consider using fresh sliced chili peppers or a dash of sriracha in addition to or instead of red pepper flakes.

cooked rice (for serving)

Serve with jasmine rice for an authentic Thai experience. You can also use brown rice for added nutrition or even cauliflower rice for a low-carb option. To enhance the rice, consider cooking it with a few crushed garlic cloves or a bay leaf.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Heat the Oil

    In a large skillet or wok, heat 2 tablespoons of vegetable oil over medium-high heat. Make sure the oil is hot enough to shimmer but not smoking.

  • Step 2: Sauté Garlic and Onion

    Add 2 cloves of minced garlic and 1 medium sliced onion to the pan. Stir-fry for about 1 minute until fragrant. This step builds a flavorful base for your stir-fry.

  • Step 3: Cook Chicken or Tofu

    Add 1 pound of sliced chicken breast (or tofu for a vegetarian option) to the skillet. Cook until browned and cooked through, about 5-7 minutes. Ensure the chicken is fully cooked by checking that it reaches an internal temperature of 165°F (75°C).

  • Step 4: Add Bell Peppers

    Stir in 1 cup of sliced bell peppers and cook for another 2-3 minutes until they are tender-crisp. This adds color and crunch to your dish.

  • Step 5: Incorporate Sauces

    Pour in 3 tablespoons of soy sauce and 2 tablespoons of oyster sauce (or a vegetarian alternative). Stir to combine all ingredients evenly, letting the flavors meld together.

  • Step 6: Add Thai Basil and Seasoning

    Finally, add 1 cup of fresh Thai basil and 1 teaspoon of red pepper flakes (optional, for heat). Cook just until the basil wilts, about 1 minute. Be careful not to overcook the basil to retain its vibrant color and flavor.

  • Step 7: Serve

    Serve the stir-fry hot over 4 cups of cooked rice. Enjoy your delicious Thai basil stir-fry!

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I properly slice chicken breast for stir-fry?

To slice chicken breast, place it on a cutting board and ensure it’s semi-frozen for easier handling. Cut against the grain into thin strips, about 1/4 inch thick. This helps the chicken cook quickly and remain tender.

What can I use as a substitute for fresh Thai basil?

If you can't find fresh Thai basil, you can use regular basil or even mint as a substitute. Keep in mind the flavor will differ slightly, but it will still add a fresh taste.

How do I know when the chicken is fully cooked?

Chicken is fully cooked when it reaches an internal temperature of 165°F (75°C). You can also check that the juices run clear and the meat is no longer pink in the center.

What is the best way to prepare bell peppers for stir-fry?

For stir-fry, wash the bell peppers, remove the stem and seeds, then slice them into thin strips. This helps them cook quickly and evenly.

How can I make my stir-fry more flavorful?

To enhance flavor, make sure to use fresh ingredients and season well. You can also experiment with adding ginger or a splash of lime juice at the end for brightness.

What should I do if my stir-fry is too salty?

If your stir-fry ends up too salty, you can balance it by adding a little sugar or honey to counteract the saltiness. Alternatively, add more vegetables or rice to dilute the saltiness.

How can I prevent my stir-fry from getting soggy?

To prevent sogginess, make sure to cook over high heat and avoid overcrowding the pan. Cook in batches if necessary to ensure everything gets a good sear.

What’s a good way to store leftover stir-fry?

Store leftover stir-fry in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. Reheat in a skillet over medium heat or in the microwave until warmed through.

Can I use frozen vegetables in my stir-fry?

Yes, you can use frozen vegetables, but add them directly to the pan without thawing. They may need a few extra minutes to cook compared to fresh vegetables.

What type of rice is best to serve with stir-fry?

Jasmine rice is a popular choice for serving with Thai dishes, but you can also use brown rice, basmati, or even quinoa for a healthier option.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

For a vegetarian option, use tofu instead of chicken and ensure the oyster sauce is a vegetarian version. This dish is naturally gluten-free if using gluten-free soy sauce. Additionally, for those avoiding soy, coconut aminos can be used as a substitute for soy sauce. The dish can be made low-carb by serving it over cauliflower rice instead of traditional rice.

Pairings

This Savory Thai Basil Stir-Fry pairs excellently with jasmine rice or coconut rice due to their subtle flavors that complement the stir-fry's boldness. For a heartier option, consider serving with quinoa or brown rice. For beverages, try pairing with a light lager or a fruity white wine like Riesling. Iced Thai tea or coconut water can also be refreshing choices.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the stir-fry hot directly from the skillet or wok for a casual dining experience. Garnish with additional fresh Thai basil and lime wedges for an extra burst of flavor. Consider serving with a side of spring rolls or a fresh cucumber salad to add a refreshing crunch. If hosting, present the dish family-style in a large bowl, allowing guests to help themselves, creating an inviting atmosphere.

Savory Thai Basil Stir-Fry

25 min
$12
350 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 4

Allergens:

SoyShellfish (if using oyster sauce)

Dietary Tags:

Gluten-FreeDairy-Free

Cuisine:

Thai

Course:

Main Course

Tags:

Quick MealOne-PanStir-FryHealthy

Description

A quick and flavorful stir-fry featuring fresh basil, colorful veggies, and your choice of protein, all tossed in a savory sauce!

Ingredients

  • chicken breast (or tofu): 1 lb
  • fresh thai basil: 1 cup
  • bell peppers (sliced): 1 cup
  • onion (sliced): 1 medium
  • garlic (minced): 2 cloves
  • soy sauce: 3 tbsp
  • oyster sauce (or vegetarian alternative): 2 tbsp
  • vegetable oil: 2 tbsp
  • red pepper flakes (optional): 1 tsp
  • cooked rice (for serving): 4 cups
